Sutra: Moreover, the wonderful auspicious... is neither real nor existent. Commentary: The second major section below
tames the minds of the two vehicles and clarifies great compassion to break through nonexistence. The two vehicles only benefit themselves
and are bound by the grasping of dharmas;

now it is said that the wonderful wisdom and skillful means of great compassion are explained, so it is called taming the minds of the two vehicles and clarifying great compassion to break through nonexistence, because those who cling to emptiness lack great compassion.
The text has three parts:

first, observing the characteristics of illness; later, giving rise to great compassion.

Sutra: When observing in this way... gives rise to great compassion.
Commentary:
This is the arising of great compassion.
One should not give rise to compassion like ordinary beings who have attachment, nor like the two vehicles who give rise to compassion based on the two views.

Or, according to the following text, one should not give rise to compassion based on giving rise to attachment to various samÄdhis, or give rise to compassion based on views and attachment, or give rise to compassion without the wisdom of skillful means. Or, one should not give rise to compassion based on seeing and grasping their true attachment to fame and profit, but only give rise to great compassion in order to eliminate the adventitious afflictions of all sentient beings.
What should not be done before is what should be done later.
Sutra: Why is it so? Because there is weariness.

Because there are no bonds, one can attain the great liberation of nirvana.

Commentary:

If one is bound oneself and does not liberate the bonds of others, one is an ordinary person or a two-vehicle [disciple].
Because one can liberate oneself, one can liberate the bonds of others, like the Tathagata and others.

This meaning is explained as follows:

Sutra: Also contemplating the body and mind, up to this is called wisdom.
Commentary:
Second, explaining wisdom.

The sick person who is provisionally born from the combination of the five aggregates relies on this function of being oppressed by suffering. These two have been mutually dependent since beginningless time. The later arises and the former ceases, never for a moment not arising. It is not that what has never arisen before is now newly born, nor that what has not ceased before is now ceasing.
Moreover, if it is said to be newly existent, then it is the old sickness;
if it is said to be the old sickness, then it is newly produced moment by moment.
Knowing that the body and sickness have arising and ceasing moment by moment, therefore it is said to be neither new nor old.
Sutra: Not seeking the body and mind, up to this is called skillful means.
Commentary:

The two vehicles know that the body and sickness arise and cease, and seek ultimate cessation, forever entering nirvana, which is called lacking skillful means.
Bodhisattvas are not like this. They do not seek permanent cessation, therefore they have skillful means.
The wisdom of both vehicles exists, but is not possessed by ordinary beings.
Skillful means is not possessed by the two vehicles, but is only possessed by bodhisattvas.

On the fifteenth day of the fifth month in the dingmao year of the Wuku era, this scroll was proofread and completed. There are many errors in this scroll.
For difficult proofreading and correction, the original text is retained;

However, among the two pages of three or four, the subject and object are mixed up and difficult to understand. When confronted with criticism, without paying attention, I have supplemented for the young and ignorant, using my own understanding to interpret the sutra, and turned it in order.
